description: The bit flip channel is the simplest non-trivial quantum noise model, applying a Pauli X operation with probability p. This flips |0⟩ ↔ |1⟩, analogous to a classical bit error.

While rarely the dominant error in real hardware, the bit flip channel is important for pedagogical purposes and appears in simplified noise models. It can also model certain readout errors where the measurement outcome is flipped.
The bit flip channel is a Pauli channel, making it amenable to standard QEM techniques and compatible with stabilizer-based error detection.
physical_examples: Readout errors (misidentifying |0⟩ as 1 or vice versa)
Simplified model for teaching quantum error correction
qem_considerations: PEC can exactly cancel with known error rate
Symmetry verification can detect bit flips that violate conserved quantities
